Description: Floor and foot sherd of Attic black-figured pottery plate with low, flaring ring foot; interior: brown band around perimeter; black-figure frieze: probably confronted sirens (of left siren only slight remains, withadded red on chest; that on right has red on neck, wing, and tail band); at right, hindquarters and wing (both with red) of sphinx to right; small and large incised blob rosettes as filling ornament; below, triple dot band; in centre of tondo, parts of an animal; exterior: standing surface of foot reserved; inner and outer faces black; part of black-figure decoration consisting of large siren, to left (wing and tail remaining; red on tail band); incised blob rosette as filling ornament.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The sherd is also published in Callipolitis-Feytmans, D., Les Plats attiques à figures noires. Paris 1974, 344, no. 30, fig. 45 (profile).
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 351-2, no. B443)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 226, no. 8)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0800) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 92, pl. I, no. 21)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
